Understanding the Modern Military
Career Pathways

Navigating Education Benefits

Since all service members are encouraged to pursue higher education, the military has a variety of programs to help students pay for many kinds of post-secondary options, to include certifications, licenses and apprenticeships, etc. Read the stories below and select the options that might be most beneficial for each case.

Dana Jones

Young woman wants to be a paramedic. Her parents have saved up for her to attend college. During her senior year, disaster strikes, and her college fund is suddenly unavailable. She’d still like to pursue a career in emergency medicine. What are her options?

  • Enlistment as Active Duty, Full-Time

    If Dana enlists in Active Duty, she can start earning her degree right away. The tuition assistance program will pay up to 100% of the cost of tuition and expenses and she’ll be earning a salary and room and board for her service. When Dana graduates she will be completely debt-free and she will have experience in the field.

  • Enlistment in Reserves, Part-Time

    Once Dana graduates with a degree in health sciences, she can elect to join either as an officer or as an enlisted Servicemember and have her qualifying student loans repaid. She also could have the choice to pursue more specialized medic duties such as Special Operations Combat Medic if that line of emergency medicine is interesting to them.

  • Rebecca Church

    Once Dana graduates with a degree in health sciences, she can elect to join either as an officer or as an enlisted Servicemember and have her qualifying student loans repaid. She also could have the choice to pursue more specialized medic duties such as Special Operations Combat Medic if that line of emergency medicine is interesting to them.

Rebecca Church

I will be 17 when I graduate (I was skipped a year) and I want to be a police officer. The local police academies are not taking 17 year olds.

What are some of my options? I don't want to wait until I am 18.

  • Career options may be available in the US Armed Forces/Military

    Ms. Church will need to review the services she has an interest in and identify whether that service has jobs/careers as a police officer (military police) or not. What are the requirements for military police?

  • US Army Reserves, Part-time

    While serving, Ms. Church can attend traditional college with a major in criminal justice/law and pursue her career as an Army Reserve Police Officer.

  • US Army Active Duty, Full-time

    Active Duty enlistment (full-time) as a military police officer would afford Ms. Church the opportunity to work in her field of choice, gain relevant job skills, education and training that is transferable to equivalent civilian law enforcement careers (Michigan State Police, local county/city law enforcement departments, FBI, CIA and etc.).

Taylor Thomas

I love watching cooking competitions on YouTube and “Iron Chef”. I think it would be amazing to be a chef at a big hotel or celebrity restaurant.

  • Enlist in an active duty component with cook or chef as MOS

    Taylor can combine on the job training with culinary arts classwork while becoming proficient in their job. They will not have any student loan debt and be prepared to work in a large kitchen environment and be guaranteed a job as a chef regardless of the economy. They will also be eligible for VA small business loans if they decide to open their own business.

  • Attend community college with a strong culinary arts program while serving in a reserve component

    Taylor can get both on the job training and coursework in the Military and civilian sectors. They will likely graduate without student loan debt and be likely able to work and serve in their chosen field in their home area.

  • Attend culinary school

    Taylor can attend a dedicated culinary school and graduate as a trained chef. This option may require moving for education and is quite expensive: tuition alone runs about $30,000 and employment as a chef upon graduation is not guaranteed.

Jay Lopez

I’ve always wanted to be a reporter. I love being on the scene and in the middle of things while using my talents to tell people what is really happening and why they should care.

  • Go to a four-year university with a well-respected journalism school.

    Jay can take classes in journalism, mass communications and writing to lay the foundation for being employed as a journalist. If the school is well-connected, an internship will be a critical part of breaking into the broadcast business. Jay will likely have to relocate to a different market to start a career in broadcasting. With rapid changes in media, it is uncertain what the future will look like for broadcast and other journalists. There may also be significant student debt involved in reaching this goal.

  • Enlist in the active military as a broadcast journalist

    Jay will take classes in journalism, mass communications and broadcast technology as part of the advanced training as a journalist. Jay is guaranteed a job and experience as a broadcast journalist without student loan debt.

  • Enlist in the Reserves as a public affairs specialist

    Jay will combine journalism classes with other training as a public affairs specialist. Part of Jay’s training will be in broadcast journalism and Jay will gain experience in multiple aspects of public communications which will make combining this training with a relevant civilian job easier.

Payton Johnson

I really want to be an orthopedic surgeon. I like the idea of being able to make people even stronger than they were. I'm good at science and math and I like to make things with my hands. My brother was born with a clubfoot and a surgeon changed his life.

  • Go to a four-year college, graduate in a pre-Medical or science field and be accepted to an accredited medical school.

    If qualified, Payton can apply for the Hebert Armed Forces Health Specialist Scholarship to pay for all of medical school plus a living stipend. They will incur a service obligation of one year for each year of support, but can specialize while completing residency.

  • Go to a four-year college, graduate in a pre-Medical or science field and graduate from an accredited medical school. Specialize in orthopedics after medical school while doing residency.

    Payton could join the US Army as a direct commission physician. The Army will pay off qualifying loans and Payton can specialize while completing residency

  • Enlist in the military in any specialty and apply for the Enlisted to Medical Degree Preparatory Program.

    EMDP2 allows Servicemembers to remain on active duty while undergoing two years of preparatory coursework. The courses would enable Payton to comple the two-year prep, pass the MCAT, attend and graduate medical school and complete the follow-on residency requirements, and return to active duty as an officer in the medical field.
